item.title: Hotly-Anticipated Action RPG Crimson Desert Has Finally Gone Gold
item.content:encoded:
Developer and publisher Pearl Abyss has announced that its highly-anticipated open-world action RPG Crimson Desert has gone gold at last, so it's finally safe to start getting excited for that March release date.

In a post on X, the studio thanks Crimson Desert fans (and, presumably, Black Desert fans as well) for their support during the former's development and invites players to stay tuned for further updates on the game.

Pearl Abyss accompanied the announcement of Crimson Desert's completion with a photograph of the game's staff members in a celebratory pose, which is rather endearing (and which rather brings home the fact that the game really is coming out soon).

Just as a reminder, when a game "goes gold", it essentially means that the master copy of the game, i.e. the one from which all other copies will be created, is complete. In essence, it means that the game is ready to ship.

Crimson Desert was first announced all the way back in 2019, with a trailer showing off gameplay for the title appearing at The Game Awards in 2020.

Following that, however, in July 2021, Pearl Abyss delayed Crimson Desert indefinitely, citing the usual need to "create the best possible experience" upon the game's release.

Pearl Abyss continued working on the game in the years that followed, and after one last delay, a release date of March 19th was finally revealed. It now looks as though the studio will be able to keep to this latest release date.

Though Crimson Desert began life as a prequel to Pearl Abyss' Black Desert Online, it eventually morphed into a standalone adventure.

Taking place in the world of Pywel, Crimson Desert features an in-depth combat system with plenty of moves and tactical options to master, as well as a range of other activities including fishing, hunting, and cooking.

You'll be able to play Crimson Desert when it launches on PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S on March 19th. Be sure to check out our very own Andrew Otton's preview of the game to see what he thought.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Enshrouded 1.0 Coming to PC and Consoles in Fall as Keen Games Shares Fun Stats
item.content:encoded:
Keen Games has revealed that its survival-crafter Enshrouded will be getting its 1.0 release this fall after two years in Early Access, and what's more, the studio has shared some fun stats to commemorate the game's second anniversary.

In a post on Steam, Keen reveals a new roadmap which confirms that Enshrouded 1.0 is set for release on PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X|S this fall, but before then, there will be one more major update that will bring Adventure Sharing to the game.

Adventure Sharing will enable players to "share their world with the community", and it'll arrive in version 0.8 of Enshrouded, together with a round of general balance improvements and bug fixes.

When Enshrouded 1.0 does arrive, you can look forward to a host of new features and improvements, including a better new player experience, "greater tactical depth" and "smarter enemy behavior" in combat, and lots of new content, plus more.

In addition to sharing news of Enshrouded 1.0's release window, Keen Games has also revealed some fun stats to commemorate the second anniversary of the game (which is coming up in a couple of days), and players have been pretty busy enjoying the world of Embervale.

In total, Enshrouded players have spent 20,901 years playing the game (collectively, of course), and have destroyed 30 million shroud roots, placed 1.3 billion blocks of water, and farmed 1.3 billion plants.

The world of Enshrouded hasn't been content to rest on its laurels and let all of this happen, though; 420,402 players have drowned in the game, and 52.5 million deaths from fall damage have been registered as well. Be careful out there.

Additionally, Enshrouded has crossed the five million sales mark at last, so it's managed to pick up another million sales for itself since April last year. I'm rooting for you, guys!

Enshrouded is available right now on PC via Steam Early Access, and it's coming to PS5 and Xbox Series X|S this fall. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: The Killing Stone Is A 17th-Century Occult Adventure With Deckbuilding At Its Core - Developer Interview
item.content:encoded:
The Killing Stone is a new roguelite deckbuilding game with an added focus on a "17th-century occult horror narrative." This focus on story might not be as common for the genre, but for the team at developer Question, this story was always something they'd had in mind.

Last week TechRaptor had a chance to sit down with the team at Question, as well as Liam O'Brien and Emma Gregory who lend their voices to The Killing Stone, to learn more about the game and the process of putting it together.

At the top of our discussion, it was revealed that The Killing Stone will release on February 18, 2026 for PC via Steam. If you're interested in trying out the game, a demo is also currently available to play.

The story of The Killing Stone takes place after the death of Mariken Swangard (Emma Gregory), a powerful mage whose success was due to various deals that she took on with One Eye (Liam O'Brien) the Devil. Those sins she took on have now been passed on to the family, and the Devil is ready to collect unless Maven, the character you play as, is able to help them get out of those bad deals.

Jordan Thomas, co-owner of Question and writer and narrative director of The Killing Stone, explained that while they didn't set out to create a game with a narrative focus it was an obsession with a Faustian theme that pushed the development of the story. They also took inspiration from "Slay The Spire, Inscription, and [I Was a] Teenage Exocolonist, but also from Firewatch, Eternal Darkness, and Seventh Guest. Not wanting to take any on in their own turf, but to do what we can to nod to them and appreciate them."

The core gameplay loop will have the player, Maven, taking on the Devil and his lieutenants by revising the contracts that One Eye has with the different members of the family. These contract changes take place through roguelite deckbuilding battles.

The Sins Are Present In The Decks You Play

Each family member has a different deck with different cards, boons, and banes. Each of these buffs is tied to the family member that they represent.

As you progress from node to node you'll encounter different battles, events, and have chances to remove cursed sin cards from your deck or power up other cards.

Talking us through the combat quickly Thomas described it as "wizard chess meets poker." Thomas also explained that each deck is "meant to start oppressive, but as you bargain with the demon, things will become easier."

Explore The Mansion Between Games

A portion of The Killing Stone that I got to learn more about was what you can do when you're not playing the deckbuilding portion of the game. Stepping up from the game table, Maven is able to explore the massive Swangard mansion.

"It's all about the atmosphere and what's lying under the surface" - Liam O'Brien

During this moment we got to see Maven move through a number of hallways and up a stairwell to a dimly lit and ominous living room with various members of the Swangard family standing around. It was explained that during the downtime you'd be able to learn more about the story and perspective on the events of the game from the characters you'll be helping along the way.

The story of The Killing Stone can definitely be explored on the surface by just playing through the game, but it's in these moments that you talk with members of the family and explore the mansion where you'll learn far more about what's going on.

Thomas praised games like Elden Ring for their emergent storytelling, teaching you about the world through character observations and item descriptions, and said that while The Killing Stone "isn't treating you like you're in school… through collaboration and discussion, more of the story can be pieced together."

Extra Hard Challenges Are Optional But Worth It

The Mansion isn't just about exploration either as you can make your way to a grotto where there are chances to complete Arcane Rituals. There are additional challenges that are difficult to complete but will grant you cards that can be cycled into any of the decks going forward, giving you access to some powerful cards.

We did ask whether there would be additional hidden secrets in the Mansion that could affect gameplay, but it was explained to us that "it's not a game where you're unlocking hidden rooms or solving puzzles, these are more ambient haunting moments and optional conversations but it's a light tough."

Audio Tracks For English and Period English

One of the most fascinating aspects of the game's 17th-century setting is that there are multiple English language tracks for the game, one where the characters speak in what I might describe as sounding like Old English, and a second that is truly period English.

"One [language track] is a little closer to modern language, there is also a second track where everything is ripped out of centuries old texts."

When the text was first shown off I thought they were beginning with the period English, that was until they toggled it on and replayed the same scene and the entire scene transformed.

Gregory couldn't be more complimentary of the experience explaining "I had the most wonderful time. I was thrilled that someone had the balls to write in period speak and that to me, I just relished it. I've done a lot of Shakespeare and I love it. There were times that Liam [O'Brien], [Jordan Thomas], and I spoke for hours."

'Modern' English
"Blood shared with me may be a component, many curses are delimited thus. Regardless, an economy of hexcraft as every my way: Meaning if any substitute soul will do, why was the child selected to absorb my sins? 
If i wished to compel the rest - er even you - to stay... would not the Damoclean Sword, dangled over his young head, do the trick via pity's soft sorcery?

'Period' English
"Mine own blood, share'd amongst my line - may a catalyst be; many curses are delimited thus. Regardless, an economy of hexcraft was e'er my way. For lo - if any substitute soul will suffice to absorb my sins, wherefore select a child? 
Were it my will to compel the rest, or e'en thee - to stay: Would not an omen of Damoclean doom o'er a young head dreadful pois'd - then, by pity's soft sorcery - hold all in check?"

O'Brien added that the deeper period English adaptations of the text were easier to get into character for and bring out a deeper performance. What added to this is that O'Brien was asked to take the role of One Eye after Thomas saw him performing in a Shakespearean manner as part of a Critical Role ad read.

"The writing is some of the richest, densest, most creatively thrilling work I've had a chance to do in a long time." - Liam O'Brien

You can also choose to mix and match these different versions of English between voice and text if you'd prefer to have Liam O'Brien speak as if he were in a Shakespearean production but have an easier to understand English as text on the screen. The game will also have localizations for French, German, Spanish (Latin American), and Simplified Chinese.

For fans of deckbuilding roguelites who have been looking for a bit more of a narrative drive, The Killing Stone is shaping up to be a game just for you. It's less than a month until its release on February 18 now.

Andrew has written Video Game and Entertainment news, reviews, and guides for 10+ years. As Senior Content Manager, he assists in creating and editing… More about Andrew
